properties.text:
Before you dive in, you should know a few things, since this pack is very different from vanilla Minecraft - and most of other packs, too. 

 At first all these new features may seem daunting, but don't worry: this guide along with tutorial quests will get you started on this grand new adventure in no time.
To properly begin your journey you need to locate the Temple. It should spawn within 100 blocks of your starting location, and is absolutely required for your progress.

Changes, explained

        
       The Player 
       Pages 2 - 4

The World 
Pages 5  - 18

Unique Features, Quests and progression
Pages 19-26

There are a few things new to your character itself, some you might be unfamiliar with.
As you may have noticed there are 3 additional bars on your screen: they represent your hydration level and body temperature, and surrounding air quality. It is important to keep track of these, or else you might start to experience negative effects. If severely neglected you will most likely die.
There are a lot of ways to hydrate yourself! You can simply right click on water in the world, or drink from a filled bottle.

However, those sources of water may not be the cleanest and you could very well get sick. Thus, any impure water bottles should be distilled by cooking them in a furnace, or you could boil water in a cauldron set over fire or lava.
Disclaimer Page 27
For more details please refer to https://github.com/Funwayguy/EnviroMine/wiki
Another neat way to keep dehydration at bay is the Camel Pack.

Next change! You are no longer Superman. That's right, your inventory now weighs something - quite a lot, actually. As you fill it up you will notice a Weight notification on the top right of the screen. The more you carry the slower you become, and once you get over the limit you will not be able to function.

So, mining carts and tracks leading down to your mine will be needed early game to prevent encumbrance.

Speaking of mining, you are now a bit dumber in that regard; but you can learn. This means you need to get used to handling all these different tools by raising your skill one glorious block break at a time.

If you need a more convenient source of water while travelling and don't want to carry so many bottles then the Camel Pack is for you. This piece of equipment is vital whenever the temperatures are high and inventory space is precious. It can be crafted together with up to 4 bottles worth of water and will automatically replenish 1% hydration every second when worn in the chest armour slot. If you feel like sharing, the filling process can be reversed to fill bottles with clean water.

properties.text: To get started, you need to craft your very own Flint Pickaxe!

Note that there will be a starting quest to guide you through these features. This section is meant for those new to changes made by IguanaTweaks, but still describes the whole process, just in case. Also note, while IguanaTweaks normally disables Flint drops from Gravel, it doesn't in Divergence.

There is a recipe, too.
To assemble the pickaxe you will need to combine a Flint Pickaxe Head, a binding and a tool rod in your Tool Station.
Start off by crafting a Blank Pattern.
Place the blank (better several) into your Stencil Table.
And craft these three patterns - Pickaxe Head, Tool Binding and Tool Rod.
Now use those in the Part Builder to build your parts.
Note that while you can't use wood or stone to craft the head, they will work for the binding and the rod.

Now you are ready to start your mining adventures in Divergence. You must rely on these tools to progress within the pack. Most of tools acquired by other means will not function in the world, and can only be used in crafting recipes. Also, you will not be able to make the Tinker Tools hammer at all. There are alternatives that will provide your area mining, most requiring some form of fuel. Here are a few:
The World!
Much is different in the world of Divergence, starting with ore generation.

Ores no longer generate in small clusters spread haphazardly throughout entire depth layers - instead, there are several distribution types, the main two of which we will go over. 
The first type is sparse ores
Every type of sparse ore generates as a single block at random heights within a chunk. When they are mined each produce a ore chunk.
You can combine 4 chunks to craft a standard ore variant.

The other type is huge veins, consisting of hundreds of connected ore blocks and stretching over a vast underground area. While it might seem like too much, bear in mind that these veins are rare: normally, a chunk would have no more than 2 or 3 of them crossing it's boundaries, and sometimes none at all.

Ores in those veins are also special in their own right: each ore an be mined several times (anywhere from 1 to 21). Each time you break oneit will drop up to three raw ore pieces.

These raw ores can ether be smelted into nuggets 
or, for a higher yield, processed into a tiny dust pile.
These huge veins come with a unique method of prospecting: each type of ore has a plant indicator that will sometimes grow on the surface over it's vein.

Additionally, using bonemeal on the ground will occasionally grow some of those indicator plants. You will get more of a specific plant the more of it's ore is available in the chunk, as far down as about 48 blocks. Indicator occurrence rate will drop off quickly if the primary ore cluster is farther than 32 blocks down.

Another prospecting method is a sluice; a proper way to set up one is shown below. The blocks covered by flowing water are sluice blocks (they look like a wooden pressure plate), you can place up to three in a row. The blocks on the side can be anything except gravel, sand, or dirt. After setting this construction up, simply toss a block of sand or gravel in. Each sluice block will take time to process your block, and in the end you will have a tiny ore dust. This entire process can be automated using Hoppers and Sifters.
Now we'll go over how to build the Mill multi block, and it's many uses.
First off, the Mill can grind sugar cane into sugar, bones into bonemeal, and wheat into flour. It can also be used as a better way to process your raw ores early on.
Insert items by hand via right-clicking them onto the edge of mill blocks, or automate it with a Hopper as shown below.
Those three blocks with hoppers directly above them can be used to automatically insert items into the mill.
The products will be ejected below the central block. You can easily catch them with a hopper.
You should check your mill to make sure if it has enough air flow. It needs to be above Y level 65 to operate.
It must be built above Y level 65 to operate.
Sifters can be automated early on as well. A Sifter will collect siftable items above it (like a Hopper), and products can be pulled out form below.
It automatically combines tiny piles of dust into large piles at 8:1 ratio, which is slightly more efficient than the hand-crafted 9:1.
This feature is very useful when used with a Mill or a Sluice, for better efficiency and automatic combination of tiny piles into proper finished product.

The Pressure Packager processes items (and some blocks) into their compressed forms, like coal to coal block or snowballs to snow. Any vanilla item that has a 2x2 or 3x3 recipe and results in a block is registered as a pressure packing recipe. Additionally, there are a few special recipes like snow to ice or ice to packed ice.
Like the Millstone, it requires a windmill to power it.
However, the primary purpose of this machine is to compact the ore chunks from sparse ores into an ore block, so that they could be processed in the usual manner.
Underground and you

A note about automated mining: while machines like the BuildCraft Quarry or Thaumcraft Arcane Bore will break and mine the ore blocks, they will only do so once. So, while manually mining a vein may yield up to 500 raw ore, automating it will bring you up to 10 times less. The only automated system that works as intended is Immersive Engineering Excavator.

Harder Underground is a set of changes to make underground exploration more dangerous, and somewhat realistic. Mining through rock is not a simple task, coupled with a multitude of dangers - such as explosive gas, smoke, and collapsing ceilings.

Stone Blocks now follow physics - but don't be alarmed, they won't immediately fall like gravel or sand. Instead, they will bear a certain load, and start to fracture should it be exceeded. After several damage stages the Stone block will break down into Cobblestone, which needs a block underneath it to stay in place - much like gravel.
Another danger that awaits you underground is gases.
Volatile Gas comes in two varieties.
Thin volatile gas is lighter than air, floats, and is almost invisible. It's also incredibly flammable and explosion-prone.

Thick volatile gas is heavier than air, sinks, and is not terribly flammable. It will put out any fires it flows onto, although it's top surface will burn for a very long time if ignited. It also might explode if an unrelated explosion happens nearby - so be especially mindful of Creepers when near a pocket of such gas.
Both varieties are displaced by water flowing into the area. It is possible to dispose of a gas pocket by repeatedly placing and picking up a bucket of water.
Smoke

Lava and fire now spawn smoke whenever a player is in vicinity (32 blocks horizontal and 16 vertical). Smoke, which is lighter than air, dissipates after a rather short time, so it won't flow very far. But it will collect in confined spaces, making navigation around lava caves difficult.
Rock Dust

Rock dust is emitted whenever unstable stone collapses. It will rapidly deplete a player's lung capacity, possibly causing damage, but will typically dissipate before killing a healthy player, even if there is no escape.

All gaseous fluids added by Harder Underground will attempt to balance their flows (unlike standard fluids, which have a constant and even downward slope), which means that a large volume of gas can spread very far. Gasses will also attempt to flow past standard non-solid blocks that block water, such as ladders, signs, and doors.

Breathing in gasses (being inside their volume) will slowly deplete entity air meters, and eventually cause nausea, non-potion blindness, and suffocation. Due to the way drowning works in Minecraft, air bubbles on the HUD will not be displayed, which makes hard-to-see gasses particularly dangerous.

Every entity has a "lung volume" calculated from their body volume, so chickens will suffocate much sooner than players; know it and use it - take a mining canary with you!  Undead, Iron Golems, and Snowmen do not need to breathe and will be unaffected.

Harder Wildlife is an alteration to the world at large. Animals breed and die, trees spread and fall, leaving behind rotting wood, seasons change, snow falls, accumulates, and melts. Crop growth is significantly slowed, and takes into account biome attributes: warm (but not hot) and wet (but not soggy) biomes will grow crops the fastest (especially during the spring and summer). Saplings and other plantables (mushrooms, sugar cane, etc.) will automatically get planted if left on suitable ground.
Crops, Seasons, Wildlife and more

It now takes more treats to make animals go into breeding mode, but they also drop more products - meat, leather, etc. More animals will drop leather now, and those that do will do so in copious amounts, making it a viable armor option for early stages - as it was meant to be! Killing a sheep will give more wool on average than shearing (shearing has the benefit of leaving the sheep alive) making it easier to build your first bed.

 Biomes that normally lack animals have their own versions (like monitor lizards and goats for mesas) that provide animal goods.
Crops
Crop growth rate is slowed to approximately 1/10th of default, and biome conditions can affect it either positively or negatively. Weeds will now grow on farms, slowing crops even more.

Seasons have a profound impact on crop growth, altering a biome's temperature and rainfall, averaging as wet in Spring, dry in Fall, warm in Summer and cold in Winter. We will talk more about season a bit further in the book.
Temperature and Rainfall

These two biome properties are the largest contributors to crop growth speed.  Generally speaking the ideal temperature is 0.8°MC to 0.9°MC (plains biome) and the ideal rainfall amount is around 1.1 to 1.2 MCU (the jungle biome is 0.95).  Crop growth declines off this peak with the most severe drop off being once the temperature drops below freezing.  Both functions are quartic (polynomial to the degree of 4) with expected input values between -0.5 and 2.5 (beyond those limits, the result will be capped to a configurable value).  As the curves are very flat at the peak values, ideal conditions are actually fairly wide ranging, but (0.8, 1.1) is assumed to be the actual peak, even though (0.7, 1.2) will have identical growth rates.

In best possible conditions crops will grow at about 1/6th of the default rate. Certain biomes are far from that ideal, and are either extremely dry (0MCU) or extremely wet (2MCU), as well as extremely cold (<0°MC) or extremely hot (>2°MC). Nether biomes are all much hotter than even the overworld desert, having a base temperature of 3°MC.
Greenhouses

It is possible to grow crops indoors - or even underground. Indoor conditions are basically outdoor conditions averaged over the seasons, so in extreme climates this will have a profound effect on crop growth, while in milder biomes it's hardly noticeable. Bear in mind that while it effectively makes all indoor spaces have comfortable temperature and humidity, it's not necessarily what a given plant would prefer.
Temperature and Rainfall Continued
Crop Climate Data

The following is a table of crops with their ideal growing conditions. These are presented using a set of offsets and the resulting ideal, in Minecraft units.  Seasons notes are relative to the plains biome. Offsets using "months" treat the year as being that many months ahead or behind the actual date. Using the thermometer and hydrometer you can get an idea of both general and crop-specific conditions.
Temperature

The thermometer will show the real or relative temperature for a given crop - right click on a crop block to link it or any other block to unlink it.

 WAILA displays temperature in °F or °C (configurable) and shows both the ambient and preferred temperature.
Rain Fall

The hydrometer will show the real or relative humidity for a given crop block - right click on a crop block to link it or any other block to unlink it.

 WAILA displays humidity in inches or centimetres (configurable) of rainfall per month and shows both the ambient and preferred rainfall.

There's now a yearly cycle of seasons. The game starts in Spring (equivalent to May 1st) and a year lasts (by default) 128 days.

 One full moon cycle is a month, with 2 months per season and 4 seasons per year.

 Thus, with 2 days per moon phase, the year is 2*8*2*4 = 128 days long.
Seasons

Spring is standard temperature, give or take, and very wet.

 Summer is warm and dry.

 Fall is colder than normal, and very dry.

 Winter is very cold and slightly wet.
Be aware that these are modifiers on top of the base, so, for example, a taiga will never thaw, even in the summer, nor will you see any ice in a desert during winter.
All this means that even the comfortable plains you have grown to love could be frozen over for a part of the year, so plan accordingly.
Wild Life

Animals will now breed, age, and expire, all on their own. If food is scarce some populations might even die out completely. It is also more resource costly to breed animals, taking on average 6 feeding attempts to encourage breeding, with each animal type having their own chance.

Drops from animals have been increased quite substantially. Cows drop more leather and beef, pigs drop more pork and additionally some leather, sheep drop multiple wool, horses also drop a small amount of additional leather. This makes hunting animals more a viable food source, especially during the early game, as well as making leather an early-game resource for armor  - as it was intended to be.
RawHide
However, note that normal leather drops are replaced by rawhide, which needs to be tanned on a tanning rack to become suitable for crafting.

One last thing to note, all herbivorous animals now require a source of food to survive; for most this means grass or leaves within a 5x5x5 area around on them. So don't put an entire herd of cows in a 1x1 milking cell and expect them to live long.
I need FOOD!

Divergence is all about being different (hence the name), ever since it's very conception. The quest and progression part is mainly covered inside the quest book. You should start out with the tutorial section and then advance through there.

The design of this pack is to integrate the quest system while still holding true to Minecraft's sandbox feel. you are not forced to complete quest for your basic items like in most packs that are built around it.

So as far as unique features goes. Most mods will require you to research/quest to acquire the ability to craft the required items to use said mod. Complete a quest gain a key. Click on the Chair inside the room to         gain the knowledge
Each type of research has 3 tiers. There is two types of items one for Tech and one for magic.
For a more in depth crafting guide go to page 23
Lets cover how to attain Steel, Platinum and Tritanium

For the sake of a clear direction in advancing to higher tier tools. You will need steel to bridge the gap normally covered by bronze in tinker tweaks. To produce Steel you will be required to use Tinkers Steel Works. While it does not have a NEI handler as of right now to tell you the recipe. It is covered in the book itself. I will go over it in a tad bit more detail along with Tritanium production which is custom to this pack. Tritanium is produced this way to cut down on needless Ore Generation.
First build your High Oven. Example below is a small oven it can be expanded up to 8 blocks high
Bottom layer solid scorched block's
Bottom and Top Layer --->
High Oven Controller,Drain or Ducks cannot be placed on the bottom or top row
A completed High Oven
<- Steel
Sulfur
Ardite Dust
Diamond
Outputs =
Redstone
Gun powder
Sand
<- Iron Ingot
Output =
Due to Platinum having few uses in this pack. Natural ore gen has been disabled. To craft use this method.
Output =
For the magic research you will be utilizing Botania's Runic Alter to craft the Amplifications. As seen below all the information you need can be found using NEI.
As an example the tier 1 Amplification requires the below items. Tier 2 requires a tier 1 and addition items. It progressively becomes much harder to attain the higher tiers.
The same goes for the Tech side how ever you will be using lasers and a Assembly Table to attain Augmentation's

The only two quest on the magic and tech lines that do not require ether Amplification's or Augmentation's Would be ether Botania For magic and Buildcraft for tech. This is due to each of these mods are needed to construct further research. Think of them as starting magic or tech.

Ok now that you know how to craft Amplifications and Augmentations. Lets show you how they will be used, Why they exist and a overview of the Quest/Research system. Below is a picture of the Tech Tree
This is located using the Quest Book provided by Hard Core Questing Mode.

So using Railcraft as a example of a Tier one quest. You have to first of unlocked BuildCraft a pre requirement. which is considered Tier 0. Without First unlocking a prerequisite you will not be able to complete a quest.

So to Unlock Railcraft as you can see in your Quest book it requires 20 Tier one or Exceptional Augmentation's. Once Completed you will receive a reward. In the case of railcraft and most quest it will be a Key.
These keys will only unlock one door within the temple.
As so all of the keys are labelled to match a banner located near the door it is used in.
Strongly Suggest you not break these banners as finding a door without them can be time consuming
So behind each door there will always be a Chair and sometimes some mod related items
The Chair being the most important block. This is used to unlock the mod so you can place blocks, Use item's or Craft.
Once you interact with the chair it will automaticly unlock ether the entire mod or parts of it. In this case railcraft. Would be completely unlocked showing a notification!

It will display similar to that of a achievement. This is a per player basis. If playing in SMP Each person will have to interact with a chair. This is good in cases that there is multiple groups that do not wish to share there knowledge freely. You can simply lock the door behind you to prevent others from attaining the research for free.
Now without completing the quest there is some indications. That will show you if the item or block is  locked. Looking through NEI
Or simply if something you attained by finding it in the world or in other shady means Does not work or you cannot place it.

There are some limitations to the "mod locking" mechanic. Autocrafting something using Applied Energistics or Logistic Pipes will still work, a block placer or a turtle can still place blocks and use items you can't yet, etc. 

 Yes, you can and will find even more ways to bypass the system. But, don't think of it as being clever: sabotaging the core principle around which this pack is built will only ruin your own experience. Should you wish to play without the restrictions you could try Divergence in creative mode, or just about any other pack out there. So, please, do not report issues related to breaking the progression - unless you're absolutely sure you know a way to fix it.
Disclaimer
ReactorCrafts Ores

Like the alternative method to get platinum mentioned earlier, some of ReactorCraft ores have been disabled - mainly due to 4-5 of them crafting a single item each. You can obtain those using the Rock Crusher from RailCraft.
